title-group.article-title: Selected Unusual Tumors of the Stomach
title-group.subtitle: A Review

article-meta.aff: 1Oxford University Hospitals Trust, University of Oxford, Oxford, UK

author-notes.corresp: Runjan Chetty, Department of Cellular Pathology, Level 1, Academic Centre, John Radcliffe Hospital, Headley Way, Headington, Oxford, OX3 9DU, UK Email: runjan.chetty@ndcls.ox.ac.uk

abstract.p: Several unusual stomach tumors have been recently described. In addition, some tumors that are often encountered in other sites may rarely occur as primary gastric tumors. The diagnostic surgical pathologist needs to be aware of some of these lesions to prevent misdiagnosis. This overview discusses the key clinical features, pathology, immunohistochemistry, and relevant molecular findings of multiple minute gastrointestinal stromal tumors and interstitial cell of Cajal hyperplasia, nerve sheath tumors (schwannoma and perineurioma), gastroblastoma, granular cell tumor, glomus tumor, plexiform angiomyxoid myofibroblastic tumor, and primary clear cell sarcoma of the gastrointestinal tract that occur as primary gastric neoplasms.

body.p: The stomach is the site of several well-described and rare tumors. Since endoscopy and biopsy are frequent, it is likely that pathologists will encounter some of these uncommon lesions in biopsies. In addition, several of the lesions may be encountered as incidental findings in resection specimens.
The purpose of this review is to cover some of the more unusual and recently described tumors that the diagnostic pathologist may encounter in routine practice.

sec.title: Small Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumors (GISTs) and Interstitial Cells of Cajal (ICC) Hyperplasia
sec.p: GISTs are thought to arise from the ICC, the pacemaker cells of the gut found in the Auerbach plexus, submucosa and muscularis propria, or primitive pluripotent stem cells. GISTs are distinct spindle cell or epithelioid mesenchymal tumors that are typically defined by expression of KIT (CD117, stem cell factor receptor) protein on immunohistochemistry1 or for equivocal cases proven to harbor activating KIT/PDGFRA mutations on molecular genetic studies.

They have no gender predilection, and although there is a wide age distribution, they mostly occur in the middle-aged and older people and are very rare in children.2,3 The majority of GISTs appear to be sporadic but tumor syndromes neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), Carney’s triad and familial GISTs are associated with an increased risk of developing GISTs.4-12 Inheritable germline KIT mutations can be demonstrated in familial GISTs, but KIT and PDGFRA mutations are lacking in NF1-associated GISTs, which are usually located in the small intestine.13 Gastric GISTs of Carney’s triad show female predilection (85%), occurring at a young age, epithelioid in type, multifocality, and lymph node metastasis, and no KIT and PDGFRA mutations were identified in 37 patients with molecular genetic studies performed by Zhang et al.14

Small or microscopic GISTs have been the recent topic of interest and different terminologies have been used to describe them, including GIST tumorlets, minute GISTs, ICC hyperplasia, minimal GISTs, micro-GISTs, and sclerosing stromal tumorlets.15 They are found incidentally in resection specimens for upper gastrointestinal cancer or detected in the vicinity of overt GISTs. GIST tumorlets were detected in 22.5% of autopsy cases in a study by Agaimy et al.16 They are common in the proximal stomach and the oesophagogastric junction (OGJ).16-19 In studies of stomach GISTs, including the OGJ, their sizes range from 0.2 to 10 mm.16,17,19 They are situated within the muscularis propria, either at the inner circular or at the outer longitudinal layer, and may extend to the subserosa (Figure 1A-C). The majority of them are solitary and clinically indolent. Of the 35 autopsy cases of Agaimy, 5 had multiple lesions and seen in 2 of 22 surgical cases. They are of spindle cell type and often associated with hyalinization and calcification.16 They frequently harbor KIT mutation by molecular analysis and PDGFRA mutation has also been demonstrated, similar to clinically evident GISTs, suggesting that small GISTs are likely to represent a precursor lesion and raising the possibility of a GIST “hyperplasia-neoplasia” sequence.16 In the recent study by Rossi et al,18 which have included small GISTs to less than 20 mm, the overall frequency of KIT/PDGFRA mutations remain lower than overt GISTs. The epidemiologic evidence that small GISTs are a more frequent finding than clinically apparent GISTs and histologically, the presence of hyalinization and dystrophic calcification suggest that small GISTs have limited growth potential and commonly completely regressed.16 Therefore, the inclusion of micro-GISTs in the new TNM tumor–node–metastasis) classification with no malignant potential seems inappropriate.

caption.p: A small gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) is identified in the outer longitudinal layer of the gastric muscularis propria (A), with hyalinized stroma (B) and KIT expression (C)

sec.p: ICC hyperplasia may be diffuse or nodular. Non–mass-forming diffuse form of ICC hyperplasia is seen in inherited syndromic and familial form of GISTs, carrying the germline mutations for KIT/PDGFRA and NF1 and to a lesser extent in the sporadic setting.20,21 GIST tumorlets are defined by lesions from 1 to 10 mm based on gross recognition and differ from ICC hyperplasia sporadic (localized) microscopic lesions.

In terms of terminology, it has been suggested that clinically silent nodular ICC proliferation that are ≤5 mm in diameter to apply the term GIST tumorlet, those that are >5 mm to be considered as GISTs and to adopt the term ICC hyperplasia for small ICC proliferative lesions with a diffuse growth pattern, regardless of size. This is somewhat similar to the neuroendocrine lesions of the lung, and although 5 mm is an arbitrary cut-off value, the term GIST tumorlet reflects the biological indolence of small gastric GISTs and translates a more clinically useful term. It is also an attempt to bring nomenclatural uniformity for further studies.15

sec.title: Peripheral Nerve Sheath Tumors (PNSTs)
sec.p: PNSTs of the gastrointestinal tract are rare benign tumors that may show schwannian, perineural, fibroblastic, or mixed differentiation.

sec.title: Schwannoma
sec.p: In a recent review of PNST of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract,22 73% of the 22 schwannomas were located in the stomach and was reported in 23 of 24 cases from an older review.23 The majority of them arises in the body and is more common in women. The patients may present with nonspecific upper abdominal symptoms or with an epigastric mass, but many were detected incidentally at investigations or surgery for other disease.

Macroscopically, the tumor size ranges from <1 to 15.5 cm. They are either circumscribed or fusiform and may exist as a single nodule or be lobulated. The cut surface of the tumor is homogenous tan yellow or white, and they are of firm to hard consistency. Multiplicity and tumor necrosis are not a feature. Tumors may grow to form a serosal polypoid mass or appear as a protruding mass into the gastric lumen with or without ulceration.

Gastric schwannomas are not encapsulated and tend to be predominantly in the muscularis propria.24 They are composed of woven compact bundles of spindle cells with tapered ends, set within loose myxoid areas.23,24 They are moderately cellular with wavy collagen fibers. Prominent lymphoid cuffs are seen in all cases22-25 (Figure 2A) but less so in the reticular variant. This is distinctly different from soft tissue schwannoma and is almost pathognomonic of gastric schwannoma. They may demonstrate microtrabecular, macrotrabecular, nested, regular whorls or storiform, and cellular growth patterns.22 Antoni A and Antoni B and nuclear palisading more typical of soft tissue schwannomas were not identified. The nuclei may exhibit benign nuclear atypia, that is, nuclear pleomorphism with uniform chromatin pattern. Mitoses are absent or scanty. Cystic degeneration and focal areas of sclerosis and confluent dystrophic calcification superficially have been described. The rare reticular/microcystic variant25,26 and a signet ring cell variant have also been reported in the stomach.

caption.p: (A) Gastric schwannoma, low-power magnification showing an expansile, nonencapsulated, circumscribed mass with an outer rim of lymphoid cuff. (B-D) Gastric perineuroma: (B) submucosal spindle cell lesion with a myxoid background, (C) classical “onion-skinning” whorled pattern, and (D) positive epithelial membrane antigen (EMA) staining

sec.p: All gastric schwannomas demonstrate strong S100 protein expression. They show variable and focal positivity with CD56 and GFAP and are negative for CD34. Scattered epithelial membrane antigen (EMA) positivity may be seen in perineural cells. They are negative for CD117, DOG-1, CD34, muscle actins, and desmin. Calretinin and inhibin are also negative.
On electron microscopy, these tumors show spindle-shaped mesenchymal cells with cell processes surrounded by basement membrane.24

The differential diagnosis includes common gastric mesenchymal tumors GIST and leiomyoma. The presence of prominent lymphoid cuff is an extremely helpful clue on hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining. The use of a panel of immunohistochemistry will be able to sort this out with GIST and leiomyoma being S100 negative. The recent concept of cutaneous hybrid benign PNST such as hybrid perineuroma–schwannoma has been described in the colon but not in the stomach.27

In these reviews,22-24 patients with follow-up data had no evidence of recurrence or new tumors. Malignant transformation of gastric schwannoma is extremely rare and has only been described in a child.28

sec.title: Perineurioma
sec.p: These are unusual soft tissue and cutaneous tumors, composed of perineurial cells that express positive immunoreactivity with EMA and are negative for S100. Extraneural intestinal perineurioma is exceedingly rare. There are only 2 cases in the current literature described in the stomach, one in a 30-year-old woman and the other in a 58-year-old man. Their clinical presentation was recurrent upper gastrointestinal bleed with hypochromatic microcytic anemia and a 12-month history of refractory epigastric pain, respectively. Both these patients did not have stigmata of NF1. Their endoscopic findings were an ulcerated mass in the lower body in the woman and an antral 0.4-cm polypoid lesion in the man.

The tumors measured 1.5 and 5 cm, and macroscopically, they were described as an ulcerated mass with whorled, tan to whitish cut surface, and of firm to soft consistency. They were both centered in the submucosa (Figure 2B).

Gastric perineuriomas are nonencapsulated and range from being paucicellular to moderately cellular. They are composed of elongated and slender spindle-shaped cells. Their nuclei are spindle shaped, bland, vesicular, and may be buckled or show bipolar tapering. The cytoplasm is eosinophilic to clear with indistinct cell border. Interweaving fascicles and characteristic whorling or onion-skinning arrangement are present (Figure 2C). Cytological atypia and pleomorphic cells are not identified and may demonstrate low mitotic count. In these 2 case reports, tumor necrosis was absent and myxoid stroma with background inflammatory cell infiltrate of mast cells, scattered lymphocytes, and eosinophils were noted in the polypoid perineurioma.

Strong EMA-positive immunoreactivity is present (Figure 2D) and is similar to nongastric intestinal and soft tissue perineuriomas. CD34 positivity is demonstrated in 1 of the 2 tumors and not unexpected since it can be observed in 2 of 10 intestinal perineuriomas and 64% of the soft tissue perineuriomas. CD56 positivity is supportive of a PNST. S100, CD117, smooth muscle actin, muscle-specific actin, desmin, and cytokeratin markers are negative.

sec.title: Gastroblastoma
sec.p: Epithelial–mesenchymal biphasic tumors are rare in the stomach and carcinosarcoma or sarcomatoid carcinoma would constitute the majority of cases seen in older patients. Gastric synovial sarcoma and teratomas tend to occur in the younger age group or in the latter, during early infancy. A relatively new entity gastroblastoma was first described by Miettinen et al.29 To date, there are 4 cases reported in young adults.29,30

Gastroblastomas are relatively large lobulated or multinodular tumors and may be solid and cystic with varied cut surfaces: hemorrhagic, yellow grey, pink tan, pink, red, or mottled. They can be in the body or antrum, occurring as an exophytic polyp, ulcerated and transmural or extends from the superficial muscularis propria into the subserosa.

Microscopically, they resemble the blastemal cells of childhood biphasic blastomas: pleuropulmonary and nephroblastoma. The dominant spindle cell component shows uniform, mildly atypical, single to ovoid cells with blunt-ended nuclei. The epithelioid component may consist of condensed clusters of epithelial cells or form primitive to well-developed lumina with or without inspissated secretions. The epithelial component often seems to blend in with the surrounding mesenchyme, demonstrating a less demarcated epithelial–mesenchymal transition. The cytoplasm is pale eosinophilic to clear with a distinct cell border resembling glycogenated squamous cells. No nuclear palisading or vacuolization was identified. The mitotic counts reported were extremely variable: from minimal (0-1) to conspicuous (30) per 50 HPF (high-power fields). Mitoses were seen in the spindle cell component in the lower mitotic group and observed in both spindle and epithelioid components in the higher mitotic group.

On immunohistochemical studies, the spindle cell component displays positive immunoreactivity with vimentin and CD10. They lack smooth muscle markers (desmin and actin), CD34, KIT expression, and estrogen receptor. The epithelial component is positive for cytokeratin markers (AE1/3, CK 18) and negative for CK20 and EMA. Both components are negative for CD34, CD99, actin, desmin, calretinin, p63, S100, TTF-1, CDX2, and neuroendocrine markers. KIT expression was negative in all 3 cases from Miettinen’s group29 whereas DOG1 was seen focally in both components in 1 case. The single case from Shin et al30 differed by having a predominant epithelial component, more mature in appearance and had KIT and CD56 expression whereas CD10 was focal and weak.
Follow-up did not reveal recurrence or metastases including disease-free 14-year survival in one with a 15-cm tumor.

sec.title: Glomus Tumor
sec.p: Glomus tumors are rare lesions arising from the neuromyoarterial canal (the canal of Sucquet-Hoyer) or glomus body that is responsible for thermoregulation. The vast majority is distributed in the digits, palms, and soles but they can occur anywhere in the body, and the glomus tumor is thought to be a hamartoma of the normal glomus body. The first description of a glomus tumor in the stomach is ascribed to Key et al31 in 1951. Several subsequent cases have been documented.32-40 Several studies have noted a predilection for female patients in the fifth or sixth decades, but a wide age range is encountered (30-68 years). They are usually solitary, although Haque et al41 have described a single case of multiple tumors. They tend to be intramural (within the muscularis propria) lesions with a predilection for the greater curve, although not exclusively located here. Gastric glomus tumors are frequently symptomatic and are associated with epigastric pain, hematemesis with or without melaena, nausea, and vomiting.

The gross appearance varies from being a polypoid lesion with intact surface mucosa to polypoid ulcerated lesions or even red–blue nodules. Microscopic examination reveals the very distinctive morphology that is identical to the soft tissue counterpart. The small uniform cells proliferating around well-formed vascular channels are diagnostic. The tumor cells are positive for smooth muscle actin, h-caldesmon, and calponin and are negative for CD117, CD34, desmin, and neuroendocrine markers. The most important differential diagnoses are an epithelioid GIST and a neuroendocrine tumor.

The vast majority of these lesions are benign although Folpe et al42 described a case of metastasis associated with a gastric glomus tumor. The preferred surgical option is a wedge resection with clear margins, and enucleation is not advocated because of the risk of recurrence.

sec.title: Granular Cell Tumor
sec.p: The esophagus is the most common site of origin within the GIT for granular cell tumor, and cases in the stomach are rare although well described.43 They tend to occur with equal frequency in both genders in the fourth to sixth decades of life. Interestingly, at least 50% of gastric granular cell tumors occur synchronously with esophageal granular cell tumors. They occur in the proximal stomach and range in size from a few millimeters up to 7 cm. They are usually asymptomatic and found incidentally at endoscopy as yellow subepithelial masses, often simulating a lipoma although firmer on biopsy. If symptomatic, then vague upper GI symptoms are encountered, especially with larger tumors. A large granular cell tumor presenting with gastric outlet obstruction has been encountered. Grossly, granular cell tumors appear as yellow well-circumscribed nodules within the wall. Histological evaluation reveals a tumor in the muscularis propria or sometimes, submucosa that has the typical features of a granular cell tumor encountered elsewhere in the body (Figure 3A and B).

caption.p: A granular cell tumor composed of large polygonal cells with abundant eosinophilic granular cytoplasm stained with (A) hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) and (B) periodic acid-Schiff (PAS)

sec.p: The majority of tumors are benign but a malignant granular cell tumor of the stomach has been described.44

sec.title: Plexiform Angiomyxoid Myofibroblastic Tumor (Plexiform Fibromyxoma)
sec.p: Takahashi and et al45 described this entity as recently as 2007. Two years later, Miettinen et al46 described a series of similar tumors, and they advocated the use of the appellation “plexiform fibromyxoma.” For the purposes of this discussion, the 2 names will be regarded as synonymous. This is a rare tumor with an equal gender distribution occurring primarily in adults (average age of about 45 years) with a wide range of 7 to 75 years. Clinical symptoms are related to ulceration of the mucosa from the underlying lesions so hematemesis and anemia are most commonly encountered. The endoscopist usually encounters a submucosal-based or nodular mass. The mucosa may be intact, dimpled, or ulcerated. Plexiform angiomyxoid myofibroblastic tumor (PAMT) ranges in size from 2 to 15 cm with a mean of 6.3 cm. A very striking feature is the almost exclusive location in the gastric antrum. The tumor can extend to the pylorus and also may involve the duodenum in one third of cases. The gross appearance is of a lobulated, sometimes multinodular, white, red, or brown submucosal or transmural mass (Figure 4A). Rather than being projecting intraluminally, the mass often protrudes toward the serosal surface; and this is a very characteristic feature.

caption.p: (A) Gross picture of a plexiform angiomyxoid myofibroblastic tumor showing a pale fleshy cut surface. On low-power examination, the plexiform nature of the lesion is evident (B, hematoxylin and eosin [H&E]), while the constituent plump spindle cells with weakly eosinophilic to clear cytoplasm set within a vascular stroma is noted (C, H&E). The tumor cells are strongly smooth muscle actin positive (D, anti-SMA [smooth muscle antibody])
Images courtesy of Dr Kum Cooper, Burlington, Vermont, USA.

sec.p: Microscopic examination reveals a uniform spindle cell population arranged in a plexiform multinodular pattern. Individual tumor cells have bland oval nuclei and weakly eosinophilic cytoplasm. The stroma is also typical and ranges from being myxoid to fibromyxoid to hyalinized (Figure 4B and C). The vasculature within the stroma is prominent and varies from small thin-walled vascular channels to more ectatic arborizing vessels. Cytological atypia, necrosis, and a brisk mitotic rate are not seen.

Immunohistochemistry shows PAMT to be smooth muscle actin positive (Figure 4D), focal desmin, and caldesmon positive but negative for CD117, CD34, S100, neurofilament, cytokeratins, epithelial membrane antigen, and ALK.

From a histological point of view, the differential diagnosis is wide and includes GIST, leiomyoma, schwannoma, perineurioma, fibromatosis, solitary fibrous tumor, inflammatory fibroid polyp, and inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor. The application of an appropriate panel of antibodies and awareness of PAMT should result in the correct diagnosis being made.

The putative cell of origin is thought to be myofibroblastic on the basis of smooth muscle actin positive. Some cases may be more at the fibroblastic end of the spectrum whereas others may show more muscle differentiation. In view of the variable “myofibroblastic” expression, Yoshida et al47 designated these lesions “plexiform angiomyxoid tumors.”
These tumors behave in an indolent fashion, and recurrences and metastases have not been described.

sec.title: Clear Cell Sarcoma
sec.p: These are extremely rare tumors that may occur primarily in the GIT with cases described in the colon, ileum,48 and stomach.49,50 Clear cell sarcoma (CCS) of soft tissue have been regarded as malignant melanomas of soft parts in view of some morphological, immunohistochemical, and ultrastructural overlap. However, CCS is genetically distinct because of a t(12;22)(q13;q12) chromosomal translocation, leading to the formation of the EWS/ATF1 fusion transcript that has never been documented in cutaneous melanoma, and thus, is regarded as specific for CCS.51,52
Recent evidence suggests that primary “malignant melanomas” in unusual anatomical sites, especially the GIT, may also be CCS.

GIT t(12;22) CCS cases have a mean age of 45 years (higher than that of soft tissue CCS, 30 years). Almost 80% of the reported cases have occurred in men. The vast majority of cases are located in the small bowel (jejunum or ileum) with occasional cases described in the colon and stomach. The tumor size at presentation ranged from 1.8 to 11 cm, with an average of 6 cm in greatest dimension. Not surprisingly, these tumors have a propensity for metastasizing to the liver, abdominal lymph nodes, and peritoneum. Most of the patients died of their disease within 2 years of their diagnosis.
Most CCS are composed of uniform polygonal to spindle shaped tumor cells with abundant clear to eosinophilic cytoplasm arranged in a nested to fascicular growth pattern.

A delicate framework of fibrous septa envelops the tumor cells creating the nested pattern (Figure 5). Multinucleated wreath-like giant cells are often present. The nuclei are usually vesicular with prominent nucleoli. Mitotic activity and nuclear pleomorphism are usually encountered although cases with blander cytomorphology have been described. Melanin pigment can be, but is not usually, seen on H&E staining. Zambrano et al53 described an osteoclastic giant cell–rich clear cell tumor that may be related to CCS of the GIT. Nearly all cases are S100 positive, whereas about 60% are HMB45, Melan-A, and microphthalmia transcription factor positive.

caption.p: A gastric clear cell sarcoma showing cells with clear to weakly eosinophilic cytoplasm, vesicular nuclei with prominent nucleoli in a nested arrangement. In addition, multinucleated giant cells are also present (hematoxylin and eosin ×200.)

sec.p: Antonescu et al54 have described a novel variant of GI CCS in which the tumors showed little to no melanocytic differentiation both morphologically and immunohistochemically. There was no melanin pigmentation, S100 was strongly and diffusely positive, but all other melanocytic markers were negative. Only 1 case demonstrated melanosomes on electron microscopy. In addition, they described a fusion product between the EWS gene and the CREB1 gene that maps to chromosome 2q34 and is closely related to ATF1. They concluded that this novel subset of CCS occurs preferentially in the GIT and lacks melanocytic differentiation, and melanocytic differentiation is not necessary for sarcomas with gene fusions involving CREB family members.

It is still not quite clear whether GIT tumors with the t(12;22) are identical to soft tissue CCS or another tumor that is closely related. A significant proportion of GIT tumors diagnosed as malignant melanoma probably represent CCS or a closely related entity based on molecular studies. The distinction between melanoma and CCS is important from a clinical point of view and may have significant therapeutic implications. In the case of melanoma, it is assumed that bowel involvement indicates evidence of widespread metastatic disease and, therefore, carries different therapeutic options and has dire prognostic implications as well. However, if a bowel lesion is thought to be a CCS, complete resection with clear margins is probably all that is required. A primary visceral CCS should not be automatically excluded even in patients with a history of melanoma.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The purpose of this review is to highlight and increase awareness of well-known tumors that occur unusually as primary tumors (nerve sheath tumors, granular cell tumor, and glomus tumor), unusual manifestations of reasonably well-recognized tumors (microscopic GISTs), or recently described rare tumors that can occur as primary gastric neoplasms (gastroblastoma, plexiform angiomyxoid myofibroblastic tumor, and clear cell sarcoma of the GIT).

fn.p: The author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
Figure 2A was taken from Pathology Research International, Volume 2011, Article ID 952569, doi: 10.4061/2011/952569.
